results.title: Canoeing safely
results.creator_credit: Maurice Dybeck, Peter Halket and Explorer Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Canoecraft”.
Underlines some of the dangers which abound on almost every river and canal and shows ways of taking sensible precautions to avoid these dangers. Topics covered include life; hazards; paddling skills; an ‘H’ rescue; canoe buoyancy aids; weirs; capsize drill; stopper waves; emergency packs; bridges and a ‘T’ rescue.

results.title: Making a canoe
results.creator_credit: Maurice Dybeck, Peter Halket and Explorer Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Canoecraft”.
Two boys, with the help of an adult instructor, make a slalom canoe from glass reinforced plastic. The processes involved are shown step by step. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maurice Dybeck, Peter Halket and Explorer Films

results.title: Basic strokes
results.creator_credit: Maurice Dybeck, Peter Halket and Explorer Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Canoecraft”.
Shot in both still and fast moving water, shows all the simple skills needed to paddle a canoe. Shows forward strokes, sculling draw, slap support, sculling for support, reverse paddle, sweep stroke, draw stroke, low telemark and hanging draw.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maurice Dybeck, Peter Halket and Explorer Films

results.title: Fish and chips cooking library. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Simple recipes garnished with humour and a smattering of hints and tips are demonstrated by Peter Doyle of the Sydney restaurant family. He shows you everything you need to know about how to make delicious seafood meals, including how to cook a fish in your dishwasher. The video is accompanied by a recipe booklet which also includes charts which show you which fish to substitute for another, and when particular fish are in season. The video is also time coded so that you can find the recipe you want, quickly and easily.

results.title: First winter
results.creator_credit: John Smith, Roman Kroitor, Sam Grana and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This historical drama features the first winter spent in Canada by a family of Irish immigrants deep in the Ottawa Valley. The year is 1830. Because the father is working in a logging camp, the mother has sole charge of the family. Sickness overtakes her and she dies. The children are left on their own to survive. The film graphically illustrates the enormous hardships endured by the first settlers who had to cope with a climate they were unfamiliar with. Filmed in Algonquin Park.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Smith, Roman Kroitor, Sam Grana and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: First Tuesday: four hours in My Lai [anatomy of a massacre]
results.creator_credit: Kevin Sim, Michael Bilton and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the massacre of villagers (mostly women and children), by U.S. troops at the Vietnamese village of My Lai on March 16, 1968. Survivors, both villagers and soldiers, speak of their experiences, memories and how they have coped since.
results.title_for_label: First Tuesday: four hours in My Lai [anatomy of a massacre]

results.title: First Hand: five films
results.brief_description:
First Hand is a Koorie Heritage Trust cultural training and media project for young Indigenous people in Melbourne and regional areas. The project gives young Koories the skills to explore questions of culture and identity through the moving image.
During late 2004 and early 2005, participants completed training in communications, media and cultural studies, practical workshops in video production and a scriptwriting workshop held in the Screen Pit at ACMI. Community elders from metropolitan and regional areas (including Uncle Wally Cooper, Aunty Joy Wandin-Murphy and Uncle Sandy Atkinson) facilitated discussions about Indigenous culture and identity.

results.title: Possum's tale
results.brief_description:
“My country is in my heart everywhere I go. My country is in my blood no matter what happens to me. My country is my family and my community…”
This is a poetic documentary exploring the spiritual connection between Aboriginal people and the country they were born in. It recreates the childhood experience of the director, Josie Atkinson, as she attempts to return home to her country as a young child.

results.title: First Sino-Japanese War = 甲午风云
results.creator_credit: Nong Lin, Changchun Film Company and Yi Xi
results.brief_description:
The film deals specifically with two naval conflicts at Fengdao Island and the Yellow Sea, during the 1894 Sino-Japanese War. The Chinese navy encounters the Japanese on the sea and, because of secret deals and the cowardice of the Chinese officers, refuses to engage them. The ordinary seamen aboard the Chinese vessel are outraged and eventually mutiny to fight the Japanese. The mutineers later join another vessel which is captained by a die-hard patriot and fighting man who leads them to a minor victory. The film ends on this positive note that the Chinese people have always been loyal and willing to fight, and its military losses were due largely to the corrupt and weak upper classes.
The film, which can be considered as war propaganda, avoids the Chinese navy’s humiliating military defeat by blaming the corrupt officials and ranking officers, who lacked the courage and will to sacrifice for their country. These heroic qualities are instead held by those low-ranking seamen, who have been disenfranchised by China’s then feudal system. The film invokes strong pejorative cultural and moral stereotypes against the Japanese, who all dress in extravagant Western clothes and hatch vile diplomatic schemes to defraud the Chinese people from a clean and honest fight. The film should in no way be taken as a historically reliable account of the events that unfolded during the Sino-Japanese War. However, it is a keen insight into the historical revisionism and aspirations of the Chinese Communist Government which dealt a critical hand in producing the film.
(Awards: 1983 - Winner of Portugal’s 12th Festroia International Film Festival’s Jury Prize.)
(James Donald, 3 star rating, 2010).
